data.title: Indian films that won International appreciation
data.meta_description: Indian films that scored big abroad. Indian films that won International appreciation. Indian films often have a reputation of just being masala potboilers.
data.text:
Indian films often have a reputation of just being masala potboilers without real substance. Well, while our films do stick to those stereotypes there are also times when Indian movies delivered something that not only rose beyond expectations of the people in the country but also took the world by surprise. We have a put together a list of films made by Indian filmmakers that gained massive critical acclaim not only in India but also around the world, scoring big on the festival circuit. Be on the lookout for these hidden gems and make sure to add them to your viewing list.

Parched (2015)

Parched is an intense drama which stars Radhika Apte and Surveen Chawla in the leading roles. The film is written and directed by Leena Yadav. She has previously directed Shabd starring Aishwarya Rai and Sanjay Dutt and Teen Patti with Amitabh Bachchan and Ben Kingsley. The film is produced by Ajay Devgn under his banner Ajay Devgn Films. The movie is a story about four women who are living in a village situated somewhere in north western India. The village is still a victim of ridiculous traditions like child marriage and other social issues. It struck a blow for female sexuality and was known for its bold scenes. The ensemble cast was praised for its natural acting. The film was screened during the special presentations section of the 2015 Toronto International Film Festival. After the news of the film being selected for the screening broke, director Leena Yadav issued an official statement. The statement read, “It's an honour to be selected at this prestigious film festival and to be in the august company of such a great lineup of films,Parched transcends boundaries of language and culture and its themes and stories will find resonance with a global audience. Every member of the team has poured their love and passion into the film and I hope that has translated to a compelling watch on screen.”

Court (2014)

Court is a Marathi courtroom drama film. The film examines the Indian legal system through the trial of an old folk singer at a sessions court in Mumbai. The film marked the directorial debut of Chaitanya Tamhane. Along with the direction, Chaitanya also undertook the role of the writer of the film. Producer Vivek Gomber also acted as the chief protagonist of the film. Theatre ace Geetanjali Kulkarni marked her film debut with Court. It won a total of 19 awards from various film festivals across the globe including the Best Feature Film award at the 62nd National Film Awards in 2014. The film was premiered at the 71st Venice International Film Festival on 4th September 2014. It received the Orizzonti Award and the Luigi De Laurentiis (English: Lion of the Future) award at its premiere at the 71st Venice International Film Festival. It also won the Best Film Award and Best Director Award for Tamhane at the Singapore International Film Festival, the Grand Prix and FIPRESCI Prize at the Auteur Film Festival, and special mentions at the Kyiv International Film Festival "Molodist" and FICUNAM International Film Festival.

Gattu (2012)

Gattu is a story about a nine year old orphan boy who works in his uncle's garbage recycling business and is fascinated by Kite flying. Specifically, a black kite named Kali who has remained unconquered and still flies in the sky. Gattu’s desire to capture that kite takes him to school where he begins spinning a web of lies which impress his friends and keep his hopes of someday capturing the kite.This 2012 film, which is written by K.D. Satyam and directed by Rajan Khosa received high critical acclaim by critics and film reviewers all over the world. The film was also honoured with.a special mention under Deutsches Kinderhilfswerk (German Children's Fund) category at the 62nd Berlin International Film Festival securing a high position among the few Bollywood films to win such acclaim. Rajan, at the festival told that his "film for children, adults and all humanity is about following your dream...about following your heart. It is about not taking no for an answer and about making it happen against all odds.” Gattu was screened in the Generation section, devoted to provide a platform for children and young people. Every year, about 60,000 visitors attend the screenings.

Miss Lovely (2012)

It premiered at the 2012 Cannes Film Festival. Ashim Ahluwalia, who also went on to direct Arjun Rampal’s Daddy helmed Miss Lovely. The film follows the tragic story of the Duggal brothers between 1986 and 1993 who produce sleazy sex-horror films and share an intense and mutually destructive relationship. The younger sibling — played by Nawazuddin Siddiqui — develops feelings for a mysterious young woman named Pinky (Niharika Singh) eventually leading to his downfall. The film constantly switches between genre pieces and is part hard-boiled film noir, part love story, part melodrama and part documentary. Asim earlier had doubts whether his film will be approved for a release in India, considering how stringent the censors can be sometimes. He also spoke about it in an interview with a leading daily. He said, “In India, you barely see a kiss on screen. It’s a highly censored country. Initially, when I sent Miss Lovely to the Censor Board, they asked me: ‘Are you sure you want to put this through?’ But, to his surprise the movie was passed by the censor board and the response that followed was even better than Ashim could have imagined. He said, “For a pretty wild art-pulp film with a lot of controversial content, the reaction has been incredible. It’s a small film with no studio or Bollywood personality supporting us — it was released through a small independent distributor, which is very rare in India.”

The New York Times profiled the movie and the director in a piece titled “Mumbai in the Bad Old Days”. It premiered at the 2012 Cannes Film Festival and won the National Film Award – Special Jury Award (Feature film), and Best Production Design at the 61st National Film Awards.

Peddlers (2012)

Peddlers is a film set in Mumbai and revolves around the story of a 20 year old destitute boy who gets trapped in a drug trade and a young cop who tries to bust them. The film was written and directed by Vasan Bala. Even though, he earlier could not get an approval for its release in India, the movie was selected for International Critics’ Week a parallel section at the Cannes Film Festival that discovered filmmakers like Bernardo Bertolucci and Wong Kar Wai. The film, which features Gulshan Devaiah, Kriti Malhotra, Siddharth Menon and Nimrat Kaur has also recently toured the Toronto International Film Festival. Vasan says that the audience abroad is looking for original voices from India. “They don’t want to see rehashed European films. They were taken aback with the way Mumbai is showcased in Peddlers and surprised by the projection of women having drinks and indulging in one-night stands. They’re used to seeing only conservative films coming from India,” he says. With absolutely zero filmi contacts, this aspiring filmmaker began his struggle on a blank slate. “Other than watching movies I had no other film connection. I started cutting trailers to learn editing. I also started writing for film blogs and somewhere I realised that there’s a part of me that could make a film.

Lucia (2013)

Lucia is an Kannada romantic psychological thriller film written, co-edited and directed by Pawan Kumar. The films stars Sathish Ninasam and Sruthi Hariharan in leading roles. The story revolves around an usher named Nikki, who has insomnia. After consuming a special pill, he gets entangled in a different kind of dream. Set in Bangalore, the film is a turbulent ride where the lines between dreams and reality get blurred. Lucia was the first Kannada film to be crowdfunded. It won the Best Film Audience Choice award at the London Indian Film Festival. It premiered at the London Indian Film Festival on 20 July 2013 and won the Best Film Audience Choice award at the festival. Director Pawan Kumar’s was obviously ecstatic after receiving such an honour. He said, “To win this award in the face of such powerful competition is a dream come true for me. I thank the London Indian Film Festival for selecting the film for its world premiere and would also like to thank the London audience and the Kannada community in UK for supporting the film.” This 2013 release was also among the films shortlisted by the FFI to become India's submission for Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film, the same year.

Killa (2015)

Killa is a 2015 Marathi film directed by Avinash Arun. Killa is a story of an 11-year-old boy juggling between coping with the recent death of his father and making new friends in an unfamiliar place after his mother gets a job transfer. The idea for Killa came to Avinash Arun when he was in the FTII and his father kept getting transferred from one job to another. Arun had a difficult time finding work as a cinematographer. So he decided to pitch his idea to a fellow student Tushar Paranjape, who ended up turning it into a full script. When Indian indie production company JAR Pictures showed desire to fund independent cinema from up-and-coming directors, Avinash Arun told them about his story in March 2013. The company decided to greenlight the project, and it went into production after four months. The film won the Best Feature Film in Marathi at the 62nd National Film Awards. The film also bagged the Crystal Bear for the Best Film awarded by the Children's Jury in Generation Kplus section at the 64th Berlin International Film Festival. After the film was selected for the screening, Arun spoke to the media and shared his reaction. He said, "Having a world premier at the Berlin film festival means a lot to me. I am enthralled. It's a very good news and for Marathi and as well as regional film makers in india. I will be able to represent my culture and my people on international platform.” The film was also nominated at the Asia Pacific Screen Awards for the Best Youth Feature Film.

Kharij (1982)

The title Kharij roughly translates to Case Closed. Kharij was a story about a servant boy, a minor, in a middle-class household who dies mysteriously locked in a kitchen. The happy contented family, a young couple and a child, is thrown into a psychological trauma revealing diverse shades of complexities of life in a given situation. Police enquiries, post-mortem, legal hassles coupled with the coming of the servant's father from the village add up to a claustrophobic nightmare. In order to save their faces the young couple and the family of the landlord behave clumsily and end up by accusing one another. The post-mortem report detects carbon-monoxide poisoning and, therefore, nobody's fault. The case is thus closed but the interior crisis deepens. This 1982 Bengali film by Mrinal Sen was nominated for the Golden Palm and also won the Jury prize at the 1983 Cannes Film Festival. Mrinal Sen won the award for the Best Screenplay and Nitish Roy won Best Art Direction at National Film Awards in 1983.

Party (1984)

This is a lesser-known Govind Nihalani 1984 Hindi film. The film boasted an ensemble cast of leading art cinema actors of including Vijaya Mehta, Manohar Singh, Om Puri, Naseeruddin Shah, and Rohini Hattangadi. It based on the play Party (1976) by Mahesh Elkunchwar and is basically a one night story, introducing us to various characters attending the party and showcasing the interplay of relations people have within the same social network.

It was the official Indian entry to the 32nd International Film Festival of India, New Delhi, and also took part in the Tokyo Film Festival 1985 and Asia Pacific Film Festival 1985. The film is a deeply intelligent satire aimed at the urban elite which shows people getting ready, looking forward to go, or cribbing about having to go just before going to the party. It bagged the Best Supporting Actress at National Film Award and the Best Actress at the Asia-Pacific Film Festival in 1985.
